Dear Ms. Madaj:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and Procedures
Section • (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has delayed referring foster care cases to adoption on
two occasions within the last couple of months. In one instance,
the adoption referral was made just shy of 4 months after
termination of parental rights occurred.
Investigation Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on 11/26/2024. The
same information was repeated from the allegation which was
termination occurred for Foster Child A (FCA) who is placed with
Relative Caregiver. Relative Caregiver was previously licensed
with Bethany Christian Services. Relative Caregiver abruptly
closed her foster home license with Holy Cross Services on 9/9/24
and moved in with the substitute caregiver of FCA.
Bethany Christian Services were aware that Termination of
Parental Rights (TPR) occurred with FCA. After the closure of
Relative Caregiver’s license with Holy Cross Services, Relative
Caregiver expressed a desire to work with Bethany Christian
Services again. FCA continued to be placed with Relative
Caregiver however through Bethany Children Services. Bethany
Christian Services had adoption case management availability
and could accept the Relative Caregiver and FCA’s case once the
case was referred for adoption. FCA’s case was not referred to
adoption until 10/21/2024. Supervisor added that a referral for
adoption has to occur within 5 business days from the receipt of
termination of parental rights order per policy and Holy Cross
received the TPR order on 8/28/2024. Supervisor did not provide
additional information.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
12/12/24 & 2/10/24. She reported she was assigned FCA’s case
in July of 2023. She reported that Chief Administrator (CA) was
functioning in several positions and was her supervisor at the
time. FCW said several staff members had abruptly departed
from the agency and a lot of cases needed attention and follow-up
with reports, home visits etc. FCW said CA asked if she needed
any help with the cases she was assigned and she asked if CA
could complete FCA’s docket for her. FCW said during that time,
2

Relative Caregiver moved a week later, after FCA’s parental
termination rights hearing and closed her license with Holy Cross
agency. FCW reported because Relative Caregiver moved and
was no longer licensed, FCA’s referral packet was not sent within
the five business days of her parents’ termination hearing as
required per policy. FCW reported that in order to make a referral
for adoption for FCA, another relative licensing home study
needed to take place, and this process was unavoidable, and that
process takes time. FCW reported she completed the home study
in October 2024. FCW reported she did not complete a follow up
with CA to determine if CA had completed the referral packet for
FCA. FCW explained she did not complete a follow up because
she assumed CA had moved forward and completed the referral
packet. She reported she felt awful when she discussed the
adoption referral packet with CA and discovered CA had not
completed the referral packet for FCA. FCW reported it was a
chain of unfortunate events and that she completed the home
study on Relative Caregiver and the adoption referral packet for
FCA was late, but it was completed in late October 2024.
Interview with Chief Administrator (CA) via video conference
on 11/26/2024. CA reported she was working in several roles
during the time that FCA’s referral packet needed to be submitted
for adoption. She reported she was FCW’s supervisor at the time
as well as Interim Chief Administrator. She reported that 2024
has been the most difficult year with staffing and the agency was
going through a transitional period of losing numerous staff in key
roles such as supervisors and foster care workers due to being
terminated for various reasons and/or staff leaving the agency
without notice. CA reported she was filling in those positions/roles
until additional staff was hired. CA admitted her agency dropped
the ball of submitting FCA’s referral packet five days after parental
rights termination hearing due to staff not performing their job
duties and leaving a mess that had to be cleaned up. CA reported
as the director of the agency she was dealing with case changes
and a combination of other errors within the agency. CA admitted
that FCA referral packet was one of those errors that occurred.
CA reported this is not a pattern of her agency and FCA’s referral
packet was late but has been completed. Since then, the agency
has hired additional staff. CA admitted FCW asked her to
complete the referral packet for FCA and she neglected to follow
through due to completing many other functions such as home
visits, parenting time, report writing and the referral packet for
FCA was on her list of to do’s and she did not get to it timely. CA
reported she was very familiar with the referral packet when a
child’s permanency plan is adoption and the TPR has occurred for
3

a child. She reported however at the time; the agency referral
process was not followed. She had no additional information.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• FCA’S case record. FCA was born 12/26/22 and placed with her
maternal aunt and uncle on 12/28/22 where she currently resides.
All medical/dentals are up to date. She is in the process of being
adopted by her Relative Caregivers.
• Relative Caregiver case record. FCA was placed with Relative
Caregiver upon exiting the hospital on 12/28/22. FCA’s case
transferred to Bethany Children Services on 11/5/24. Adoption
Assessment was completed on 12/27/24. It is expected that FCA
will be adopted with Relative Caregiver by or around June 2025.
• Agency procedure/statement on foster care referral for adoption
once the child’s termination of parental rights has occurred is the
agency will receive the order from the courts and submit a referral
packet to MDHHS for the agency to move forward with the child’s
permanency plan.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance. Based on interviews and
documentation, FCA’s foster care referral packet for adoption was
not submitted following the termination of her parents’ parental
rights on 8/28/24. The agency did not follow their written process/
procedure for the foster care referral services for adoption for FCA
required per the CPA foster care policy and procedure for foster
care per the rule.
Conclusion Violation Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
